content: AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE PRIORITY HEALTH CARE TO VETERANS OF THE PERSIAN GULF WAR. Inpatient care eligibility for veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code. Inpatient care eligibility for veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code to include hospital and nursing home care for disabilities without conclusive medical evidence. Amendments are made to allow outpatient care for veterans described in specific paragraphs. Amendments to title 38, United States Code expand inpatient care eligibility for Persian Gulf War veterans exposed to environmental hazards. Outpatient care is also allowed for veterans meeting specific criteria, including potential exposure to toxic substances before December 31, 1994. The amendments to title 38, United States Code expand eligibility for inpatient and outpatient care for Persian Gulf War veterans exposed to environmental hazards. Medical services may not be provided for disabilities found to have resulted from causes other than exposure to toxic substances. The guidelines issued by the Under Secretary for Health state that medical services for Persian Gulf War veterans exposed to environmental hazards should not cover disabilities from causes other than toxic substance exposure. The effective date for the amendments is August 2, 1990, and veterans can request reimbursement for care received before the enactment of the Act. The Act allows reimbursement for care received by veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War. The amendment extends eligibility for care for exposure to dioxin or ionizing radiation until June 30, 1994. The Act extends eligibility for care for exposure to toxic substances until December 31, 1994, and allows the maintenance of a regional office in the Philippines until the same date. Section 315(b) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to change the date from "March 31, 1994" to "December 31, 1994." The purpose of amending section 8151 of title 38, United States Code, is to improve care for veterans by allowing the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources. Additionally, the definition of "health-care resource" in section 8152 now includes hospital care, medical services, and rehabilitative services.
